<ul>
<li><p><math display="inline">a_{1}= 5</math>, <math display="inline">a_{2}= 5  + 2  \cdot 4</math>, <math display="inline">a_{3}= 35</math></p></li>
<li><p>Rather for <math display="inline">n \in \mathbb{N}^{\ge 4}</math> <math display="block">a_{n}=3a_{n-1} -  2 a_{n-3}</math></p></li>
<li><p>For each of the strings generated by <math display="inline">a_{n-1}</math> we could naively just add the numbers which will satisfy the property that the absolute difference between any two consecutive numbers is <math display="inline">\le 1</math>, there would be 3 options, one for each of <math display="inline">-1, 0,  + 1</math>. Letâ€™s assume we append to the end of the strings generated by <math display="inline">a_{n-1}</math>.</p>
<li><p>This would give us <math>3a_{n-1}</math></p></li></li>
<li><p>If any one of the strings ends with a <math display="inline">1</math>, then there are only two options, we may add <math display="inline">0</math> or add <math display="inline">1</math>, we cannot subtract <math display="inline">1</math> because <math display="inline">0 \not\in \left[ 5 \right]</math> , the same argument holds for <math display="inline">5</math> just that we cannot add one to it. Therefore the number of invalid strings we are accounting for are the ones of length <math display="inline">n-1</math> that end with <math display="inline">1</math> or <math display="inline">5</math> is given by paritioning all strings in <math>a_{n-3}</math> based on their last character and then constructing a string that ends with <math>1</math>or <math>5</math> '''SEE THE ATTACHED TABLE!'''<math display="block">a_{n} = 3 a_{n-1}  - 2 a_{n-2}</math></p></li>
<li><p>We have for any <math display="inline">n \in \mathbb{N}</math> <math display="block">a_{n + 3} -  3a_{n + 2} + 2a_{n}= 0</math></p>
<ul>
<li><p>In terms of advancement operators that is <math display="block">\left( A^{3}  -  3 A^{2} + 2 \right)f =0</math></p></li>
<li><p>Let us rewrite <math display="inline">A</math> as <math display="inline">x</math> for clarity.</p></li>
<li><p>Seeing that <math display="inline">x = 1</math> satisfies the above, we search for a polynomial <math display="inline">\alpha x^2  + \beta x  + \gamma</math> such that <math display="inline">\left( x  - 1 \right)\left(\alpha x^2  + \beta x  + \gamma  \right)= x^{3} -  3x ^{3} + 2</math>, after performing some algebra we have <math display="inline">\left( x  - 1 \right)\left( x^{2} - 2x  - 2 \right)=x^{3} -  3x ^{3} + 2</math> so by the quadratic equation we obtain <math display="inline">x = 1 \pm  \sqrt{3}</math>, so the full factorizaiton is <math display="inline">\left( x - 1 \right)\left( x  -  1  + \sqrt{3} \right)\left( x  - 1  - \sqrt{3} \right)</math>, that tells us that the general solution is of the form <math display="block">c_{1}1^{n}  +  c_{2}\left( 1 + \sqrt{3} \right)^{n} +  c_{3}\left( 1  -  \sqrt{3} \right)^{n}</math></p></li>
<li><p>Using the fact that we know <math display="inline">a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}</math> we will determine what the coefficients are.</p>
<ul>
<li><p>When <math display="inline">n = 1</math> we get <math display="block">5 = c_{1} + c_{2} ( 1 + \sqrt{3}) + c_{2} ( 1 - \sqrt{3})</math></p></li>
<li><p>When <math display="inline">n=2</math> we get <math display="block">13 = c_{1} + c_{2} ( 1 + \sqrt{3})^2 + c_{2} ( 1 - \sqrt{3})^2</math></li><li>When <math>n = 3</math><math display="block">35 = c_{1} + c_{2} ( 1 + \sqrt{3})^3 + c_{2} ( 1 - \sqrt{3})^3</math>
</li><li>And then using, for example an augmented matrix and solving the linear system, one obtains that <math display="block"> c_1 = \frac{1}{3} \text{ and } c_2 = \frac{1}{6} (5 + 3 \sqrt{3}) \text{ and } c_3 = \frac{1}{6} (5 - 3 \sqrt{3})
</math>
</li><li>To obtain the full solution, just substitute these values into our original solution we wrote</p></li></ul>
</li></ul>
</li>
<li><p><math display="inline">F\left(x\right)= \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_{n}x^{n}</math>, then <math display="block">\sum_{n=4}^{\infty} a_{n}x^{n} = \sum_{n=4}^{\infty} \left( 3a_{n-1}  -  2a_{n-3}  \right) x^{n} =  3  \cdot \sum_{n=4}^{\infty} a_{n-1}x^{n}  -  2  \cdot \sum_{n=4}^{\infty} a_{n-3}x^{n}</math></p></li>
<li><p>Which can be written in terms of <math display="inline">F\left(x\right)</math> as <math display="inline">3  \cdot  \frac{F\left(x\right) -  \left( a_{1}x  +  a_{2}x^{2} \right)}{x}  -  2  \cdot \frac{f\left(x\right)}{x^{3}}</math></p></li>
<li><p>Then we can see that <math display="block">F\left(x\right)= a_{1}x  +  a_{2}x^{2} +  a_{3}x^{3}  +  \sum_{n=4}^{\infty} a_{n}x^{n}= 3  \cdot  \frac{F\left(x\right) -  \left( a_{1}x  +  a_{2}x^{2} \right)}{x}  -  2  \cdot \frac{f\left(x\right)}{x^{3}}</math></p></li>
<li><p>Multiplying everything by <math display="inline">x^{3}</math> gives <math display="block">F\left(x\right)x^{3}= a_{1}x^{4}  +  a_{2}x^{5} +  a_{3}x^{6} + 3  \cdot  \left( F\left(x\right) -  \left( a_{1}x  +  a_{2}x^{2} \right) \right)x^{2}  -  2  \cdot F\left(x\right)</math></p></li>
<li><p>Isolating for <math display="inline">F\left(x\right)</math> gives <math display="block">F\left(x\right)x^{3} + 2F\left(x\right) -  3F\left(x\right)x^{2}= a_{1}x^{4}  +  a_{2}x^{5} +  a_{3}x^{6}  - 3 \left( a_{1}x  +  a_{2}x^{2} \right)x^{2}</math></p></li>
<li><p>And finally</p>
<p><math display="block">F\left(x\right)= \frac{a_{1}x^{4}  +  a_{2}x^{5} +  a_{3}x^{6}  - 3 \left( a_{1}x  +  a_{2}x^{2} \right)x^{2}}{x^{3} + 2 -  3x^{2}}</math></p></li></ul>
